content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    # filter down to Audi A4 and A4 Quattro models
    filtered = df_cars[df_cars.manufacturer .== "audi" & (df_cars.model .== "a4" | df_cars.model .== "a4 quattro"), :]
    # add a new column with all values set to true
    filtered[:audi_a4_type] = true
    return filtered
end
```

This function `audi_filter` takes in a DataFrame `df_cars` and filters it down to only the rows where the manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". It then creates a new column called `audi_a4_type` which has all values set to true. The resulting filtered DataFrame is returned as output.
